author: Gene D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2018
review_content: I've used a number of thumb drives over the years. SanDisk Cruzers have always been in my list of go-to drives for design and dependability. When my 6-year old 16GB Cruzer  was no longer big enough to hold all my portable apps and music, I knew I had to turn to another Cruzer for the same performance and guaranteed life expectancy. Why Cruzers, you might ask. Well, my 16GB  went through the wash a number of times and still worked after allowing it to dry out before using it. I also lost it in my garden while I was weeding the garden in the Fall. When planting in the Spring, I found the drive in the dirt. I cleaned it off with rubbing alcohol and let it dry out. After snow, rain, frost, thaw, etc., the darn thing still chugged along after I plugged it in. At that point, for me, I was sold on Cruzers for life.Admittedly, for me, transfer speeds aren't a major concern. I only use the drives for portable apps and music storage. Except for work laptops, which are newer but require encrypted devices, I use a much older Toshiba that has USB 2.0 jacks on it and have a Toyota Tacoma in which I use the drive to play music. So, 3.0 transfer speeds mean little to me and this 2.0 would work quite well. You have the option to download for free and use SanDisk's encryption software. I don't keep sensitive software on portable devices. So, I didn't have a need for it. I also reformat my drives, wiping them completely clean before using them. So, I don't use any pre-installed software, etc.The housing on this Cruzer is made of a thick plastic, quite substantial, but neither bulky nor heavy. The thing I really like about Cruzers is how the USB insert slides back in the housing to protect it; and, there is a built-in LED light that shows when the Cruzer is transferring data. The Cruzer has a small metal rod built into the housing, which would allow you to put a lanyard on it if desired. My one gripe about new Cruzers, and the reason for a four-star vs. a five, is that they no longer come with lanyards. Even cheaper drives come with lanyards. Cruzers should too, as the lanyard would allow you to attach the drive to your keys.Final Verdict: For dependability and endurance, I have no problems recommending the SanDisk Cruzer line of thumb drives. If this is anything like my old one, it'll give me (and you) years of life and data backup. If I have a reason to change my review, I'll do so ASAP. 'Til then, happy transferring.
title: You Can't Go Wrong with the SanDisk Cruzer Line for Dependability and Value

For older versions of Windows, you have to go to a Microsoft Support pages, or a file archive web portal set up by a guy called "Greyghost." It took me a long time to find "Greyghost," but I had to find him, since Microsoft had removed needed upgrade files for 32-bit Windows...For me, the flash drive was not easy to use until I watched videos online which explained the challenges of a universal file system standard. Once I understood the size limitations of FAT 32, then I was patient with operating system upgrades. You, on the other hand, may not be. author: Charles J. Kravetz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2012
review_content: I test software. One of the first things a person that tests computer software learns is that all hard drives have an expected lifetime. Whether that lifetime is 100,000 writes, or 1 million writes, or somewhere in between, there is always a lifetime. As a software tester, I often install and remove software up to 32 times in a single day. For most people, that is an extremely high number. I do it because every developer needs to know if the software they work so hard on will work. I have a good record of breaking software I test. I find bugs before the software gets to the everyday user.Along with testing software, I use my computers daily. I have installed the Linux Xubuntu operating system, the Ubuntu operating system, and the Vinux operating system. I do not like installing these often. If I use my hard drives to test with, I must reinstall much more often than I prefer. I found the ideal solution! The SanDisk Cruzer USB Flash Drive in both 8MB and 16MB are perfect for my testing. Using the Linux operating system, it fits on these drives. I am then able to test using a clean installation any program the developers needs tested. Yes, these USB drives are rated for a certain lifetime. However, that lifetime is very high. To have the ability to test as much as I do, without ever losing my own installed operating system and programs is wonderful. To be able to use these Flash Drives in place of a hard drive is great. To be able to effectively close the drives when they are removed from my computers helps keep them protected from physical damage.When I travel, I carry one of these Flash Drives with me with my email program installed. This allows me to use any computer with internet access to check my email and not install anything on the borrowed computer. I also leave no traces behind, since my Flash Drive has all the information on it.I have actually tried many USB Flash Drives. Not all drives are created equal. I have found the SanDisk Cruzer to be of very high quality. Not only do they last for a very long time, they do not break with repeated use. I do not keep these drives plugged in to my computer full time, thus they are plugged in and removed almost daily. They have a slide locking feature that protects the drive plug when not in use. To activate the slide, the user must push down a small tab in the slide. Normally your thumb does it as you slide. If you release the slide, you can push it all the way and it will lock, either open or closed. The case is a little thick, and if you have many devices plugged into the computer, it may not fit. I do not find this any thicker than most of these drives, however. I can highly recommend the SanDisk Cruzer USB Flash Drive for most users.I should say that while my operating system of choice fits nicely on these, Microsoft Windows will not. Windows users can still use them in place of a hard drive, however. It is great to be able to install a program to these, test it, and remove it.

review_content: Be really careful when you buy a USB drive nowadays.  Make sure you can see the tip of it where it goes into the computer. If it's a cheap drive for a system backup, a class at school, or something disposable then great, but I have some years old ones and the metal is scrapped really bad.  If it were plastic that drive would probably be ruined or have left a plastic residue inside the computer USB ports that's unlikely to be good for it.  So yes, this is metal and that's a very good thing!To start off I don't like sliders.  I like caps.  I put the drives in a carrying case so the cap is irrelevant, unless I want to put it in a pocket or something then no dust gets in.  Still, the feel of this one is impressive and enough to make me look at this closer.  I should note, there are some similar looking SanDisk drives that are sort of more barrel shaped where this is a rectangle.  I really don't like those other ones as the slider is more narrow and sometimes doesn't stick right for me.  This one felt solid and the slider stayed put and didn't make me feel like it'd give out anytime soon.  I'm surprised, but I'm actually happy with this.  The only downside, it's a bit too fat for some USB ports and reminds me of those wide, white, Kingston flash drives.Speed was pretty good and I moved files off a memory card in about 35 minutes, though the slowdown was probably more the memory card than the USB drive.  It is only USB 2.0, but unless you're moving a lot of big files frequently it's not a huge deal.  I've always cared about price and quality more than speed.  Price/Quality/Speed.  Pick two and a drive is a good buy.

author: Phil (San Diego)
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2012
review_content: I wanted a large USB storage device, either 32 or 64 GB. I wanted a reasonable price because for what these things go for at Target or Worst Buy or perhaps even some grocery stores, the brick and mortar tax would have made the transaction not worth doing. But I didn't just want some generic USB keyfob.My point of reference was an old Lexar JumpDrive that I'd had back in the Windows XP days. Its selling point was that it could be configured with a secure, hidden partition. Set that up before any data is loaded and you can balance the public and private partitions to whatever size you want. This SanDisk Cruzer's product description seemed to make this a good replacement for next generation compatibility.After a few days of use this device seems adequate but not ideal. The executable for secured storage is contained on the flash drive. It creates a password-protected "vault" on the flash drive. To use the secured storage you run the executable and enter credentials to access the vault. A window appears into which you can drag and drop files and folders. Once the data to be secured has been dropped onto the vault interface, the equivalent of an hourglass appears. The duration of this hourglass depends on how much data is to be copied or moved to the flash drive. I tried this on a couple different computers as well as attempting to copy data from a NAS device. A few hundred MB took anywhere from one to three minutes.There was one exception though. One folder coming from the NAS device took so much longer than I would have expected that after an hour or an hour and a half I stopped the transfer. I'm thinking that may be due to the NAS device, though I can't say for sure. But the next day I opened the vault on a different computer. Because I'd stopped the transfer the day before I wanted to see what had and had not copied over. Transfer from the flash drive to another PC took so long that again I just stopped it because I had things to do. This brings up the biggest gotcha for the SanDisk Cruzer:You cannot access your secured data while it is in the vault.To write to files in the vault, you have to copy the file(s) or folder(s) over to the PC to which the keyfob is attached. Now, I'm not working with national security or anything, but the folder containing financials is something I want to keep secure. Having to copy data from the vault to the host PC puts that information on the system's hard drive, which is counter to the logic of data security in the first place. At that point your formerly secure data is retrievable by common forensics tools until you run a professional disk wiping utility. Oh, the instructions say that you can move the data to the public partition of this USB drive, but it still begs the question, why should you have to go through this dance of data back and forth?Here's a second drawback: the vault is not discreet.The value of a USB storage device like this is that it's large enough to contain all of your critical records. A few years ago fires raged throughout the county and evacuees were lining the streets. With an emergency situation you want to be able to grab your critical data and go. Because you're mobile, you need data security in case the flash drive falls out of your pocket or otherwise gets lost. Let's say somebody finds your flash drive. Once you've created the vault, it is clearly evident as a "Vault" folder on the device. That folder can be browsed, though contents are obscured through encryption. The Lexar method, in contrast, was more refined. Although the Lexar executable resided on the USB device, there was no other evidence of the keyfob being partitioned or having a secured partition. Conceivably someone could find that Lexar device, wipe it clean by opening it in Windows Explorer and deleting its contents, and never know there was still a secured hidden partition.Consider this 32 GB SanDisk Cruzer to be a small data warehouse. Get this if you just need a secured second copy of critical data but you don't intend to work with it. The SanDisk Cruzer might be a decent choice for an emergency preparedness kit.

The older Cruzer's did not accidentally pop out because the buttons were a little stiffer to press.Another issue I have with this flash drive is that it is a little big bulky in comparison to the older Cruzers. It's unlikely that you can stick in two of these side by side or plug it in next to another USB device.So how can SanDisk improve the next generation of the Cruzer? The first thing the company needs to do is design a smaller case.
